pullRequest.title: http dispatcher: serialize all dispatch and state management
pullRequest.bodyText:
Description: Previously cancel had the contract that by the time a call to cancel returned, no further dispatch would occur for a stream. This was guarded by some atomic state on the stream. While this was actually one of the more tested areas of the codebase, we're unwinding that for now, and dispatching cancellation the same as any other stream interaction. This is to potentially simplify reasoning about the code to continue investigation of recent crashes. Some tests have been removed that specifically tested concurrency of cancellation, since ordering tests now cover this.
Risk Level: Moderate
Testing: Local and CI
Signed-off-by: Mike Schore mike.schore@gmail.com

nodes.bodyText: I still don't understand why this boolean is necessary. Once a stream is pending destroy, it should be gone from the map and the map lookup on stream ID should fail. Can you try to remove this boolean and simplify the logic further?

It is extremely difficult to reason about when the stream is removed from the map in various scenarios and with early returns. Per my other comment, can you remove the pending destroy boolean, and change the logic in all of these functions (with a cleanup RAII object, etc. whatever) to a) ASSERT the stream is still in the map, and b) remove it if end_stream/reset in a way that is easy to audit without going through every early return path?
